stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes a new rideable soap-bar mechanic (with bubble particle trail) and begins designing an oil-slick cleanup interaction tied to the soap. In parallel, he revisits UI/UX plans for a redesigned star select screen using per-course panoramas, weighing ROM-size and visual-quality constraints.
stream_context.significance_reason: The stream contains concrete feature progress (soap-bar ride/decay + new particle work) plus a key UI direction for the star select screen. It also includes a personal safety/harassment incident that could inform the documentary’s portrayal of public-facing dev life.

findings.summary: Kaze frames the overworld as a rescue-island where water could “return over time,” and is open to reusing water-level manipulation ideas from an earlier concept ("World Dry World"), but says porting that system back would take too long and is deferred far into the future.

The team is pursuing a redesigned star select screen where each course is represented by a small panorama capturing the level’s “vibe.” Kaze prefers this direction but dislikes his current implementation; he highlights Biobak’s mock as already working better.

Kaze rejects using per-course 320x240 prerendered images as star-select backgrounds due to ROM cost (estimating ~0.3–0.5MB per course) and poor emulator presentation (blurry, not upscaled). He argues a lightweight 3D rendered scene/panorama can be cheaper and look better.
Kaze notes he previously removed original MK64 background assets, saving ~0.3MB of ROM, reinforcing how tight ROM budgets are for UI/background flourishes.

He implements a rideable “soap bar” by reusing Koopa-shell-like behavior/action state, including tuning collision so side contact mounts reliably. During implementation he discovers an existing interaction mechanism (a “ridden object pointer” / interaction type) he hadn’t realized existed, and adapts to it.

A debugging detour reveals his attempt to offset Mario while riding failed because his camera movement was synced to Mario’s update path, masking the position changes. After locating the update function, he restores expected behavior and confirms keys/state reset properly.
By stream end Kaze considers the soap-bar mechanic largely complete for the day: rideable, time-limited disappearance, and a working bubble particle trail tuned for density and layering.

Kaze’s custom particle system is positioned as a necessity: he claims SM64’s original particle approach would reload textures per particle, making effects like dense bubbles impractical. He also hits pipeline constraints (e.g., nthcolor disabled in his repo due to fuzz64), forcing implementation adjustments.

He begins designing an oil-slick “cleaning” interaction: the soap should be consumed even when not cleaning (to prevent players from using it as permanent traversal). For visuals, he explores reflective/rainbow ideas, but gravitates toward a simpler black oil puddle that is dynamically erased where Mario passes (deleting alpha/pixels), acknowledging it will be "a pain" to program.

Kaze reports receiving a rape threat (as a male) for the first time, describing it as shocking compared to the more common death threats he’s seen. He speculates it may have been from a young, overly-identified “philosophy” fan who lashed out after perceived disrespect toward philosophy.
Kaze says he’s excited about hosting F3 this year and claims it will be the “best F3 yet,” with roughly ~100 prize submissions but only a subset accepted.
He mentions an unnamed veteran tool author (from ~20 years ago) contacted him about building a new version of their tool, but Kaze refuses to share details yet.

Kaze briefly reports off-stream progress: over the week he fixed all bugs found in OnlyUp64, including enabling reliable ledge grabs and making certain wall jumps work more consistently than in original SM64 (with the side effect that players can kick up some walls).

biobak.summary: Biobak provides a star-select panorama concept that Kaze views as significantly stronger than his own early attempt, helping set the direction for the new course-selection UI.
Biobak requests a bubble visual that fades toward white; Kaze attempts to implement this via color pipeline changes (eventually needing to work around disabled nthcolor in his repo).

When Kaze’s microphone accidentally mutes mid-discussion, he explicitly asks Biobak to judge the oil slick look; Biobak responds positively ("Looks fantastic"), effectively greenlighting the current direction.

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly joins while at work; the interaction underscores Kaze’s casual, at-home dev environment and the way personal life overlaps with live development (he jokes about being “held hostage”).

findings.summary: Lilaa participates in technical brainstorming around compression and implementation tradeoffs (e.g., suggesting compression approaches for images/backgrounds and proposing modeling approaches for oil puddles).
Lilaa pushes back on Kaze’s tendency to deviate from the original plan (“gone rogue”), reflecting the team’s ongoing tension between scope/discipline and experimentation.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I, as a male, have gotten a rape threat. That’s insane.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze recounts a first-time, shocking harassment message, contrasting it with the more common death threats he’s received.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Adding visual flare is important to the game. You can’t just not add visual flare to the game.
memorable_quotes.context: Spoken while iterating on bubble/soap visuals, capturing his philosophy that polish and readability are not optional even on constrained N64 hardware.

key_stories.title: Building the rideable soap-bar mechanic (and making it feel readable)
key_stories.summary: Kaze prototypes a new traversal/utility object: a soap bar you can ride like a Koopa shell, with a clear collectible-like presentation and a bubble trail. The segment shows how small behavioral/visual tweaks (collision, timers, particles, layering) are essential for player readability and “feel.”
key_stories.challenge: Create a soap bar that Mario can mount reliably, ride temporarily, and understand as an interactive/collectible object, without looking like a random asset.
key_stories.process: Kaze reuses Koopa-shell action/state logic, adjusts collision to allow side mounting, tunes ride duration/disappearance, and builds a dense bubble particle trail using his custom particle system. He debugs offset/camera-update interactions and iterates on particle color/alpha behavior (including workarounds for repo/pipeline limitations).
key_stories.outcome: By the end of the stream, Kaze considers the soap bar and bubble effect essentially working and ready to be paired with the next mechanic (cleaning oil slicks).
key_stories.key_quote: Guys, I think we’re done with the bubble. I think we’re done with the soap honestly—we programmed the whole soap bar just today.

key_stories.title: Designing an oil-slick cleanup interaction under N64 constraints
key_stories.summary: Kaze begins the next gameplay loop: oil puddles that can be cleaned by riding/using soap. The story illustrates his iterative approach—exploring flashy ideas (reflective/rainbow) before choosing a simpler, more controllable visual that he can actually ship on N64.
key_stories.challenge: Make an oil puddle that visibly “cleans up” as the player passes, ideally with a believable sheen, while keeping geometry/texture memory and rendering constraints manageable.
key_stories.process: He explores dynamic textures and normal-mapped reflectivity, realizes several approaches break UV/alpha assumptions, and pivots toward a CPU-side ‘eraser’ concept: delete alpha/pixels where Mario has traversed, potentially darkening touched regions. He tests hue-shift/vertex-color tricks and checks with Biobak for approval.
key_stories.outcome: Direction converges on a mostly black oil puddle that gets erased by traversal, with a plan to implement the heavier programming work next stream.

key_stories.title: Harassment enters the dev’s personal life mid-stream
key_stories.summary: While casually working, Kaze discloses a disturbing harassment message (a rape threat), adding a real-world pressure layer to the public development process. The moment can contextualize why boundaries, moderation, and mental load matter for creators shipping fan projects in public.
key_stories.challenge: Processing a threatening, sexually violent message from a stranger, reportedly the first such message he’s received.
key_stories.process: Kaze describes the message’s context (first interaction, then block), compares it to prior experiences with death threats, and speculates on possible motivations and age/immaturity of the sender.
key_stories.outcome: No direct resolution in-stream, but it marks an emotional data point that could inform how the documentary addresses the costs of visibility.
key_stories.key_quote: Death threats? Sure, everyone’s gotten some of those. But rape threats as a guy? What the fuck?

open_questions.topic: Star select panoramas: final implementation and memory budget
open_questions.context: Kaze and Biobak are moving toward per-course ‘vibe’ panoramas on the star select screen, but Kaze is unhappy with his current version and is balancing ROM size, emulator appearance, and rendering approach (3D vs 2D images).
questions: What did the final star select solution end up being—fully 3D panoramas, some hybrid, or a different approach entirely?
How did you set a concrete ROM/memory budget for “presentation features” like this without starving level content?
What were Biobak’s original mockups, and what specific elements made them feel more ‘right’ than your first attempt?

open_questions.topic: The unnamed ‘20-years-ago’ tool author building a new tool
open_questions.context: Kaze hints that a major legacy SM64/N64 tool author contacted him about making a new tool, but he declines to share details on stream.
questions: Who was the tool author who reached out, and what was the tool’s historical importance to the SM64 modding scene?
Did their new tool meaningfully change your workflow on Return to Yoshi’s Island (asset pipeline, debugging, build times, etc.)?
What made you hesitant to talk about it at the time—privacy, uncertainty, or community expectations?

open_questions.topic: Oil slick cleanup: shipping a ‘dynamic erase’ effect safely
open_questions.context: Kaze’s favored oil-slick plan is to dynamically erase alpha/pixels where Mario passes, but he anticipates the implementation will be painful and earlier experiments looked “genuinely awful” before iteration.
questions: What was the hardest technical pitfall in making the oil puddle erase effect stable (buffering, coordinate mapping, performance, artifacts at edges)?
How did you test and prevent edge cases like leaving the course mid-clean, camera angles causing visual popping, or the cleaned state persisting incorrectly?
In hindsight, was the ‘simple black oil’ decision primarily aesthetic, technical, or schedule-driven—and did you ever regret not chasing the reflective look?
